Award.AwardTitle: Pre-Alliance Planning for the Coalition for Promotion of Underrepresented Minorities in Academic STEM (PUMA-STEM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations to successfully complete high quality degree programs in STEM.

Concordia University will engage in a 18-month planning process aimed at creating an alliance of institutions, including K-12 schools, in Illinois to achieve the goals of the LSAMP program. The planning process includes development of an infrastructure based on best practices and research in a coordinated, effective and efficient process to reduce barriers for underrepresented minorities in STEM-related fields.

The expected outcome of the planning process will be strong established and coordinated partnerships from high school to university to employment in STEM. The model, with its multi-tiered approach including implementation of best practice pedagogy, social and/or financial supports, will result in increased enrollment and graduation from STEM majors as well as a diversification of the STEM workforce. The partnership structure also provides for future expansion of the high school-college-industry network to improve outreach and strengthen the overall academic foundation for underrepresented minorities in STEM programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016, a Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) grant funded the Promotion of Underrepresented Minorities in Academic STEM (PUMA-STEM) Pre-Alliance. This pre-alliance consisted of six institutions in the Chicago area, three primarily undergraduate institutions (Concordia University Chicago, Dominican University and Elmhurst College), an applied microscopy institution (Hooke College of Applied Sciences, and two high school partners (Oak Park and River Forest High School and Proviso Math and Science Academy) with a shared goal of increasing enrollment and graduation of underepresented minority students in STEM majors to aid in diversifying the STEM workforce.

PUMA-STEM called attention to issues of college readiness, dual credit programs, recruitment and retention, career/graduate services, and student mentoring of underrepresented minority students at workshops held at the pre-alliance institutions. At all of these workshops, administrators, faculty, staff and students from alliance institutions, as well as other institutions in the area, were in attendance. The workshops allowed development of educational materials (such as lists of relevant publications and resources) for interested college and university faculty, staff, and administrators.

In addition to the workshops, PUMA-STEM collaborators collected data related to student demographics in STEM programs at the alliance institutions and compared them to the surrounding communities. Information on the use of active learning at each alliance institution was collected to compare different strategies at each institution and identify successful models to be implemented. PUMA-STEM also sought out and identified local community and industry partners, and developed a business and community partner outreach plan to reach out to additional potential partners in the Chicago area. Our efforts to expand the PUMA-STEM alliance resulted in five additional academic partners, four primarily undergraduate institutions and one community college in the Chicago area. This larger alliance developed a full NSF LSAMP STEM-Pathways Implementation Only grant that was submitted in November, 2018.  

A publicly accessible website for PUMA-STEM was developed, which includes links to resources for all five workshops including summaries, resources, and evaluations. This website and social media accounts (PUMA-STEM Twitter and Facebook) will allow expansion of the network of individuals, academic institutions, and industry partners with the common goal of increasing success of underrepresented minority students in STEM programs. This developing alliance can be used as a model for similar institutions outside of the greater Chicago area.
